head.title: A New Crop of Bathing Beauties

hedline.hl1: A New Crop of Bathing Beauties

abstract.p: Personal Shopper column on designer bathroom fixtures and decorative hardware; photos (M)

block.p: THREE European companies that offer designer bathroom fixtures and decorative hardware are opening their first American showrooms in the New York area this month. Even though European designs have been available here, it used to take some hunting and foraging in disparate places to piece together an entire bathroom. For those not intending to completely renovate, there are other new products this spring, including a mirror in a spiffy brushed-aluminum frame and an ingenious hookless shower curtain that will quickly enliven a tired-looking, winter-worn bathroom.

1. At its first American showroom, Valli & Valli, an Italian manufacturer of bathroom accessories and decorative hardware, is offering a medicine cabinet and mirror with a gooseneck light ($670). Valli & Valli is at 150 East 58th Street.

THREE European companies that offer designer bathroom fixtures and decorative hardware are opening their first American showrooms in the New York area this month. Even though European designs have been available here, it used to take some hunting and foraging in disparate places to piece together an entire bathroom. For those not intending to completely renovate, there are other new products this spring, including a mirror in a spiffy brushed-aluminum frame and an ingenious hookless shower curtain that will quickly enliven a tired-looking, winter-worn bathroom.

1. At its first American showroom, Valli & Valli, an Italian manufacturer of bathroom accessories and decorative hardware, is offering a medicine cabinet and mirror with a gooseneck light ($670). Valli & Valli is at 150 East 58th Street.

2. Boffi, an Italian distributor of European bath fixtures, will open its first American showroom on May 20. Designed by Piero Lissoni, Boffi's artistic director, the showroom will offer Boffi's own collection of bath accessories and fixtures as well as products from five other European manufacturers; 31 1/2 Greene Street (Grand Street).

3. The Mood, a squared bathtub designed by Marten Claesson Eero Koivisto and Ola Rune for a town house renovation in Stockholm, is made of Corian. Inspired by a Japanese-style tub, it is deep enough to cover a bather's shoulders; $3,500 at Boffi.

4. A new line of reproduction sinks and faucets is available from Pottery Barn's new Bed and Bath catalog. A classic pedestal sink is $449. The Belle Epoque style (shown) is $1,899. Chrome or brass vintage-style faucet sets are $299 to $329. From the catalog only; for information, orders or a copy of the new catalog, (888) 779-0557.
5. Droog Design's ceramic tiles, with a surface pattern of water drops come in red, blue, green, black or white. Each six-inch-square tile is $10 at Moss, 148 Greene Street (Houston Street).
6. A 13-inch-diameter mirror in a 16-inch-square brushed-aluminum frame by Umbra is $85 at Amalgamated Home, 9 Christopher Street (Greenwich Avenue).

7. The Baby Devoro toilet, 10 1/4 inches high, was designed for toddlers and elementary-school-age children. It is available for $328 from American Standard's distributors; for locations, www.americanstandard.com or (800) 524-9797.

8. A faucet set designed by the English architect David Chipperfield for tubs and sinks at the Bryant Park Hotel, opening soon in Manhattan, cost $375 to $600. The manufacturer, Czech & Speake, has just opened an American showroom in Hoboken, N.J.; (800) 632-4165 or www.czechspeake .com for information. The ceramic and steel sink, also by Mr. Chipperfield, was made in Italy by Ideal Standard for the Bryant Park Hotel and will be available later this year; for information, (212) 935-1033.

9. The hookless shower curtain is made with built-in grommets. The curtain comes in fabric or vinyl and in solid colors and patterns, from checks to underwater scenes. From $15 to $30 at Bed, Bath & Beyond, 680 Avenue of the Americas (19th Street).
